Literature Review: The study of crowd dynamics and multiagent systems has gained significant attention in recent years due to its wide-ranging applications in various fields, including traffic management, robotics, and social sciences. This literature review aims to explore the recent developments in modeling and control of multiagent systems, with a particular focus on crowd dynamics characterized by complex social interactions and large-scale systems.Modeling approaches for multiagent systems can be broadly categorized into microscopic and mesoscopic scales. At the microscopic level, individual agents are modeled using ordinary differential equations (ODEs) that capture their behavior and interactions. Helbing and Molnár (1995) introduced the social force model, which has become a cornerstone in pedestrian dynamics modeling. This approach treats each pedestrian as a particle subject to social forces, including desired direction, repulsion from obstacles, and interaction with other pedestrians.Building upon the social force model, Cristiani et al. (2011) proposed a multiscale modeling framework that bridges the gap between microscopic and macroscopic descriptions of crowd dynamics. Their approach allows for the integration of individual behaviors and collective phenomena, providing a more comprehensive understanding of crowd behavior.At the mesoscopic scale, the evolution of the probability density of agents is described using partial differential equations (PDEs). Bellomo et al. (2012) presented a comprehensive review of kinetic models for active particles, which can be applied to crowd dynamics. These models provide a statistical description of the system, capturing the collective behavior of agents without tracking individual trajectories.The mean-field approach has emerged as a powerful tool for analyzing large-scale multiagent systems. Lasry and Lions (2007) introduced the mean-field games theory, which provides a framework for studying strategic decision-making in large populations. This approach has been successfully applied to various domains, including economics, finance, and crowd dynamics.Control of multiagent systems presents unique challenges due to the complex interactions between agents and the large-scale nature of these systems. Bensoussan et al. (2013) explored the control of mean-field stochastic systems, providing a theoretical foundation for designing control strategies in large-scale multiagent systems.In the context of traffic management, which is a prime example of crowd dynamics, various control approaches have been proposed. Piccoli and Tosin (2011) developed a multiscale model for vehicular traffic, incorporating both microscopic and macroscopic descriptions. Their work provides a framework for designing control strategies that can be applied at different scales of the system.The advent of autonomous vehicles has introduced new challenges and opportunities in traffic control. Stern et al. (2018) demonstrated the potential of a single autonomous vehicle to stabilize traffic flow and reduce fuel consumption in a ring-road experiment. This study highlights the significant impact that controlled agents can have on the overall system behavior.Multilane, multiclass traffic systems present additional complexities in modeling and control. Work by Delis et al. (2015) introduced a macroscopic model for heterogeneous multilane traffic flow, accounting for different vehicle classes and lane-changing behavior. Their model provides a foundation for developing control strategies in complex traffic scenarios.Recent advancements in reinforcement learning have opened new avenues for control in multiagent systems. Wu et al. (2017) proposed a mean field reinforcement learning framework for large-scale multiagent systems. Their approach demonstrates the potential of combining mean-field theory with machine learning techniques to address the challenges of controlling complex, large-scale systems.In conclusion, the field of crowd dynamics and multiagent systems continues to evolve rapidly, driven by advancements in modeling techniques, control theory, and machine learning. The integration of microscopic and mesoscopic approaches, coupled with the development of sophisticated control strategies, holds great promise for addressing real-world challenges in traffic management, robotics, and beyond. As autonomous systems become more prevalent, the need for effective modeling and control of large-scale multiagent systems will only grow in importance, paving the way for exciting future research directions.
